passages.text: Industrials | Global Chemicals
Eastman Chemical Company EMN| \(\) 68.83\$ In Line | Target Price/Base Case: \(\) 75.00\$ Commentary
Market Capitalization (M)$7,90452-Week Range$56.78 - $114.50Shares Outstanding (M)115Float (M)114Average 10-Day Volume (M)1.20Enterprise Value (M)$12,772Fiscal Year EndDec
1 Year Price History
Lingering risks of protracted destocking meet rate cut momentum. We revisit FY26 estimates and contemplate a bear scenario.

With EMN stock back trading at \(\) 68\(/shr (our note on\) \ \(58\) being oversold here), focus shifts to the interplay between low- visibility on fundamental challenges and market forces ahead of Fed rate cuts. We continue to wrestle with the potential for further negative estimate revisions from sluggish 2H inventory drawdown and the risks of this cascading into early 2026. That said, clarity on inventory progress is unlikely to come before 3Q results in late October.

In the interim, with rate cuts anticipated, Chems names may trade higher (even just on unwinds of short interest at multi- year highs) well before the 'all clear' is received on fundamental questions we pose for names such as EMN. We can see the stock fitting well into a 'rate cut' basket with high durables exposure, low expectations, high short interest, and valuation at unchallenging levels. Expect a push- pull between the bear case fears and the near- term trading dynamic for the sector.

With normalizing asset utilization drawing interest on the FY26 setup, we (a) caught up with the company and (b) sketched out a downside 2026 scenario to frame risk- reward. We revise down our base- case FY26 EBIT est to \(\) 1.22\(Bn having learned that addback of full utilization headwinds requires underlying demand recovery. Our bear case build- up by end markets and segments at a\) 7.5x\$ multiple would support a low- \(\) 60\(s share price or\) \sim 10\% \(downside from current levels. Full bridge and bear scenario details within.

From our conversations a relationship between sentiment and investment time horizon has become somewhat apparent. EMN is back trading at \(8.1x\) FY25 - inline with the 3yr avg - with the push- pull of rate cuts yet still weak demand indicators to contend with for the balance of this quarter. Our FY26 revised numbers point to 7.2x base- case and 8.0x bear- case, not unreasonable though a further clearing event for numbers could yield a better entry. Straight talk is part of the package with EMN - a quality we value - though acknowledge comes with additional volatility.

1/ What level of further demand deterioration in 2H could push asset utilization headwinds over the \(\) 75- 100\(mm guide? Mgmt sounded confident on 3Q visibility as to\) \ \(50\) mm of the 2H impact. Whether the 4Q impact is \(\) 25\(or\) \ \(50\) mm (or beyond) will be inventory drawdown rate (aka demand) dependent.

2/ Could inventory reduction, and therefore asset utilization drag, cascade into 1Q26? The company indicated it does not foresee that occurring with the demand slowdown from 2Q to 3Q already contemplated in the timeline, but acknowledged the unknown with respect to further demand deterioration. Though not our base case, we wouldn't rule out some slippage into 1Q if durables further soften.

3/ Absent demand improvement, how much of the \(\) 75- 100\$ mm headwind comes back in FY26 just due to reverting utilization rates? Here we learned our prior expectation that most/all of the \(\) 75- 100\$ mm returns was overly optimistic. EMN is pointing toward a baseline asset utilization add back of \(\sim\) 50mm without underlying inventory build.

After connecting with the company, we revise our FY26 EBIT estimate downward by \(\sim\) 35 mm reflecting more tempered expectations for asset utilization normalization. Our updated forecast is now \(\sim\) 1.22 Bn, representing a \(\sim\) 190 mm or \(18\%\) y/y improvement. This revision primarily reflects our new understanding that full add back of the \(\sim\) 75- 100 mm asset utilization headwind this year would require either demand improvement or deliberate inventory rebuild. We now factor in \(\) 50\$ mm for improved utilization vs our prior \(\) 85\$ mm addback assumption.

Despite the adjustment, our revised estimate remains modestly above street consensus of \(\sim\) 1.19 Bn, which itself implies around a \(\sim\) 145 mm or \(14\%\) increase y/y from FY25 consensus of \(\sim\) 1.04 Bn.
Key assumptions supporting our revised \(\) 1.22\(Bn EBIT est include:

- \(\sim\) 50 mm in asset utilization improvement (down from our prior est of \(\) 85\(mm), assuming only half of previously reduced production rates are restored;- \(\sim\) 75 mm in announced cost savings on top of the \(\) 75\(mm already expected in FY25;- \(\sim\) 50 mm benefit from the residual Kingsport methanolysis ramp following a 2.5x increase in recycled content production expected in FY25;- \(\sim\) 40 mm in CI feedstock tailwind as propane forward contracts indicate 69 cpg for 2026, -8 cpg lower than 2025;- \(\sim\) 30 mm offset from continued weak volumes in Fibers (both textiles and acetate tow) and sustained softness in consumer durables, autos, and packaging end markets.
Figure 1: Downward revision to our original utilization addback est brings our FY26 EBIT base case close to \(\) 1.22\$ Bn
Figure 2: \(\sim\) 35 mm lower utilization addback hits AM ( \(\sim\) 15 mm), AFP ( \(\sim\) 10 mm) and Fibers ( \(\sim\) 10 mm) vs our initial bridge
\*Compared to FY25e consensus est of \(\) 1.042\$ Bn. Source: Company Data, FactSet, Evercore ISI Research
With EMN trading at just \(\sim\) 7.0x FY26 base- case, the question we often hear is what might EBIT look like should macro conditions deteriorate further.
Here we attempt a bottoms- up build of earnings by end market and segments under a scenario where inflation pressures and unemployment ticks higher thereby further challenging consumer pocket books.
Under this compounding bear- case scenario our model points to \(\) 963\$ mm in FY26 EBIT, which is \(21\%\) below our FY26 base- case represents a \(6\%\) decline vs depressed FY25e EBIT.

A recent stock price near \(\) 70\$ /hr equates to 8.0x bear- case EBITDA - which incidentally is the stock's 3yr avg multiple (stdev \(\pm 0.5x\) ), though EMN has more recently traded in the 7.0- 7.5x range. For added context, EMN stock moving higher to \(\) 75\$ /shr would equate to market comfort with 8.4x bear- base while trading back to \(\) 65\$ /shr would represent 7.7x bear- case.

A&FP is \(\sim 35\%\) exposed to relatively stable Water & Ag end markets and \(15\%\) to Personal Care, generally defensive but somewhat susceptible to slowdowns in consumer spending. The remaining \(\sim 40\%\) exposure is to durables, coatings, and building & construction markets. While these end- skets are aheady impaired in FY25, we think an additional \(20\%\) haircut here is appropriate under our FY26 bear case. This would imply segment bear- case EBIT of \(\sim\) 488 mm - a \(\sim\) 40 mm \((- 8\%)\) decline vs our FY25 est of \(\) 530\(mm and inline with the most bearish sell- side.

Recall AM is most levered to cyclical end markets such as autos, durables, building & construction and consumables \((80\%)\) , with the remainder \((- 20\%)\) serving more defensive medical and personal care markets. We estimate FY25 EBIT at roughly \(\) 370\(mm, inclusive of a\) \ \(50 - 60\) mm destocking headwind. Reversing the destocking actions but applying a \(25\%\) haircut to the cyclical portion (equivalent to a \(\sim 20\%\) reduction for the entire segment) yields a bear- case FY26 EBIT of \(\) 345\(mm,\) \ \(25mm\) \((- 7\%)\) lower y/y vs our FY25 est and significantly more punitive than the most bearish sell- side est of \(\) 450\(mm.
Although propane forwards indicate an 8 cpg improvement for FY26, for CI we conservatively pencil in \(\) 0\(EBIT contribution in our bear- case, unchanged from our FY25 forecast.

Carrying forward the lower Fibers run rate from 2H25 of \(\sim\) 70 mm per quarter, we forecast FY26 EBIT at \(\) 280\(mm, representing a further\) 13\% \(y/y decline vs FY25e\) \ \(320\) mm. This assumes the overall Fibers business continues its gradual secular decline and destocking cascades into FY26 but partially offset by normalizing utilization.

Our bear- case assumes a Corporate EBIT drag of \(\sim\) 200 mm, in part offset by \(\sim\) 50 mm of cost savings from ongoing initiatives which is short of the stated \(\) 75- 100\(mm savings target (and\) \ \(75\) mm we credit in our base case).
Figure 3: Bear case bridges to lower y/y EBIT for all segments and less than expected cost savings
Source: Company Data, FactSet, Evercore ISI Research
Figure 4: Our bear case scenario contemplates segments earnings below both our FY25 estimates and most bearish sell-side sets
Source: Company Data, FactSet, Evercore ISI Research
Capex and dividends do not appear immediately at risk under estimated FY26 bear- case cash flows, but leave little room for error.

From our bear case EBIT of \(\) 963\(mm, adding back\) \sim \(\) 500\(mm D&A and assuming a cash flow conversion of\) 70\% \(consistent with the 5 - year avg) points toward\) \mathrm{OCF} \(of\) \sim \$ 1.02 \(Bn.

EMN has suggested FY26 capex will be lower than even the reduced FY25 level of \(\sim\) 550 mm. Penciling in FY26 capex of \(\sim\) 520 mm and a dividend commitment of \(\) 380\(mm/yr implies OCF to achieve FCF breakeven is\) \sim \$ 900 mm.

This implies \(\sim\) 120 mm in bear- case post- dividend FCF, which compares with the \(\sim\) 70 mm expected in FY25 ( \(\sim\) 1 Bn OCF guide and \(\sim\) 550 mm capex + \(\) 380\(mm dividend). Not dire though we acknowledge working capital or capex requirements could easily narrow the excess.

An alternate path to estimating FY26 OCF is to bridge from FY25 guided OCF of \(\sim\) 1 Bn and add back announced cost savings and one- time inventory drawdown impacts of \(\) 100- 150\(mm. Then from a "demand - agnostic" bridged OCF of\) \ \(1.1\) Bn apply a \(15 - 20\%\) impairment for macro deterioration. Such a sanity check method yields a lower OCF estimate and tighter nondiscretionary cash flow.

While we expect market focus on cash flow to intensify as we near FY26, our work suggests some of the more bearish assertions we hear about dividend surety would involve an even more pronounced bear macro scenario.
26 CF commitmentsCapex520Dividend380OCF for FCF breakeven900Bear case implied OCFBear case 26E EBIT963D&A500Bear case EBITDA1,463Cash flow conversion70%26 bear case OCF1,024
Source:Company Data,Evercore ISI Research
After dipping more than 2 standard deviations below the 3- year avg to 6.7x, EMN's latest ntm EBITDA multiple of \(\sim 7.7x\) remains modestly below the 8.0x avg.
Our base- case PT of \(\) 75\(/shr assumes the multiple holds in the 7.5 - 8.0x range as investors roll forward to FY26 and our base- case scenario and estimates play out.

Should the bear scenario presented above unfold, we think the multiple eventually settles around 7.5x our bear- case estimates which would equate to \(\sim\) 62/shr, or \(\sim 10\%\) downside from last.
Figure 6: We anticipate EMN's multiple to remain range-bound between 7.5 and 8.0x.
Source:Company Data,FactSet,Evercore ISI Research
Figure 7:EMN estimates by segment

1Q252Q253Q25E4Q25E2025E2026ESales2,2902,2872,1472,0818,8069,077Advanced Materials7197776146412,7512,908Additives &amp; Functional Products7337697226752,8993,000Chemical Intermediates5454635404832,0312,031Fibers2882742722821,1171,138Other54--------EBIT3112752172261,0291,251Advanced Materials1161216470371457Additives &amp; Functional Products141153119117530564Chemical Intermediates19(30)75057Fibers88817279320347Other(53)(50)(45)(45)(193)(174)
Source:Company Data,Evercore ISI Research
Our PT is informed by DCF analysis ( \(\sim 5\%\) ERP, \(2\%\) Terminal growth) and historical relative multiples.

Downside risks: exposure to a broad swath of cyclically exposed end markets to include Autos, Construction, and durable goods. Fluctuations in domestic propane price can compress margins. Upside risks: faster than anticipated economic rebound, and accelerating adoption of recycled materials.

Evercore and its affiliates, and I or their respective directors, officers, members and employees, may have, or have had, interests or qualified holdings on issuers mentioned in this report. Evercore and its affiliates may have, or have had, business relationships with the companies mentioned in this report.
Additional information on securities or financial instruments mentioned in this report is available upon request.

Evercore IS's recommendations are based on a stock's total forecasted return over the next 12 months. Total forecasted return is equal to the expected percentage price return plus gross dividend yield. We divide our stocks under coverage into three primary ratings categories, with the following return guidelines:
Outperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be greater than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
In Line- the total forecasted return is expected to be in line with the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
Underperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be less than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.

Coverage Suspended- the rating and target price have been removed pursuant to Evercore ISl policy when Evercore is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving this company and in certain other circumstances.

Rating Suspended- Evercore ISl has suspended the rating and target price for this stock because there is not sufficient fundamental basis for determining, or there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints around publishing, a rating or target price. The previous rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this company and should not be relied upon.
\*Prior to October 10, 2015, the "Coverage Suspended" and "Rating Suspended" categories were included in the category "Suspended."

FINRA requires that members who use a ratings system with terms other than "Buy," "Hold/Neutral" and "Sell" to equate their own ratings to these categories. For this purpose, and in the Evercore ISl ratings distribution below, our Outperform, In Line, and Underperform ratings can be equated to Buy, Hold and Sell, respectively.
